member.name: T:Bindable.Linq.Collections.BindableCollection`1
member.summary: This class is used as the primary implementation of a bindable collection. Most of the Iterators in Bindable LINQ use this class eventually to store their bindable results, as it abstracts a lot of the logic around adding, replacing, moving and removing collections of items and raising the correct events. It is similar to the in most ways, but provides additional functionality.
member.typeparam: The type of item held within the collection.

member.name: M:Bindable.Linq.Collections.BindableCollection`1.MoveRange(System.Int32,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0},Bindable.Linq.Transactions.ITransaction)
member.summary: Moves a collection of items from their old location (whether the items are contiguous or not) to a new starting location (where the items will be contiguous).
member.param: The new index to move the items to.
member.remarks: Here is an example of how this logic works: Index Start Step 1 Step 2 -------------------------------------------- 0: Paul Paul Paul 1: Chuck Larry Larry 2: Larry Timone Timone 3: Timone Pumba Pumba 4: Pumba Patrick Chuck 5: Patrick Patrick Operation: Move "Chuck" from ix=1 to ix=4 1) Remove "Chuck" - removedIndex = 1 2) Insert "Chuck" - newIndex = 4

member.name: T:Bindable.Linq.Iterators.Iterator`2
member.summary: Serves as a base class for all Bindable LINQ Iterator containers. Iterators are Bindable LINQ operations which take one or more collections of items, and return a collection of items. This is in contrast with Aggregators, which take one or more collections but return a single result item.
member.typeparam: The type of source item used in the Iterator.
The type of result item provided by the Iterator.

remarks.para: Whilst Bindable LINQ collections are read-only, we implement the interface because it stops WPF producing a wrapper object around the result set, which results in better performance. For more information, see: http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-gb/library/aa970683.aspx#data_binding.

member.name: T:Bindable.Linq.Iterators.ItemSorter`1
member.summary: Base class used for creating a list of comparers.
member.typeparam: The type of sort item source item.
member.remarks: This base class is used so that we can enable strong typing without the comparers needing to know the key types (K) used by the subsequent ItemSorters. See the remarks for for details.

member.name: M:Bindable.Linq.Iterators.ItemSorter`1.Compare(`0,`0)
member.summary: Compares two items, returning an integer signifying if one should be sorted above or below another.

member.name: T:Bindable.Linq.Iterators.ItemSorter`2
member.summary: A class that is nested within itself to create a chain of IComparers.
member.typeparam: The source type.
The type of key used in the comparisson.
member.remarks:
Suppose someone had the following in a LINQ query:
order by customer.Name, customer.DateOfBirth
The first part of the OrderBy would produce an OrderByIterator, initialized with an ItemSorter that sorts by the customer.Name.
The second part of the OrderBy would produce another OrderByIterator, initialized with a new ItemSorter. That ItemSorter would have the original ItemSorter (customer.Name) as its "superior", and would use customer.DateOfBirth as the "fallback" sort.
Taking this even further:
order by customer.Name, customer.DateOfBirth, customer.EmailAddress
Would result in the following graph:
OrderByIterator.ItemSorter // customer.EmailAddress .Superior // customer.DateOfBirth .Superior // customer.Name
(Note that this is in the reverse order to the LINQ query)
When the Compare method is called on the ItemSorter, it first tries its superior (which tries its superior, which tries its superior, ad infinitum).

member.name: M:Bindable.Linq.Iterators.ItemSorter`2.#ctor(Bindable.Linq.Iterators.ItemSorter{`0},System.Func{`0,`1},System.Collections.Generic.IComparer{`1},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructor.

member.name: M:Bindable.Linq.Iterators.ItemSorter`2.Compare(`0,`0)
member.summary: Compares two items, returning an integer signifying if one should be sorted above or below another.
member.returns: As described in the class remarks, we first try to use the "superior's" Compare method. Only when the superior returns "0" (same value) do we use our own IComparer.

member.name: T:Bindable.Linq.Transactions.Transaction
member.summary: This class abstracts recording of collection changed events and raising them when complete. Events can be recorded whilst locks are held, and then raised at once. It automatically figures out whether events are contiguous (i.e., you add an item at index 1, then at index two) or not and combines them appropriately.

member.summary: An interface implemented by classes that record collection changed events and package them up, before they are raised. When one class is recording a transaction, others will wait before beginning a transaction.

member.summary: Records the fact that an element was added. When the transaction is completed, an Add event will be raised.

member.summary: Records the fact that an element was moved. When the transaction is completed, a Move event will be raised.

member.name: M:Bindable.Linq.Transactions.ITransaction.LogRemoveEvent(System.Object,System.Int32)
member.summary: Records the fact that an element was removed. When the transaction is completed, a Remove event will be raised.
